awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Plant-derived Biogenic Sulfur Emissions to the Environment
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation. Professor Rabi Musah of the Chemistry Department at the State University of New York at Albany (UAlbany) and collaborators at JEOL USA, Inc., a world leader in mass spectrometry, microscopy, and other analytical instrumentation, collaborate to develop new instruments that will measure volatile organosulfur compounds (VOSC) in the air in real time. Organosulfur species enter the atmosphere from both plants and other combustion processes and once in the atmosphere, VOSCs produce pollution, acid rain and cloud formation.  The tools to be developed facilitate the study of not only the identity of organosulfur compounds in the atmosphere, but also their fate in the overall global sulfur cycle. The analytical tools and data processing software that are developed may find broad utility for analyses relevant to a range of other fields including chemistry, biochemistry, forensics chemistry, food sciences, agriculture, and medicine. Additionally, commercially available hardware and software are developed. The unique collaboration with JEOL USA Inc., extends the research capabilities of the UAlbany team. The fundamental research being performed by the team at UAlbany (i.e. investigations into the VOSC emission chemistry of vascular plants, and the study of the reactions of these compounds with other species in the environmental), occurs alongside more applied investigations at JEOL that are associated with  extending the application of novel mass spectrometry technologies to solve a number of analytical problems in environmental science.  Students and postdoctoral fellows benefit from immersion in both academic and industrial experiences, which serves to enhance their professional development.

New ambient ionization mass spectrometric approaches are being developed to enable detection of individual plant-emitted volatile organosulfur compounds (VOSCs) in air in real time. The techniques are used for laboratory studies of the kinetics and products of the reactions of these newly discovered plant-derived VOSCs with environmentally-relevant free radicals. The developed analytical tools are expected to find broad utility for analyses relevant to a range problems in other fields. This work is performed in collaboration with scientists at JEOL USA Inc. The fundamental research is performed by the team at UAlbany, while JEOL pursues more applied investigations aimed at extending the application of novel ambient ionization mass spectrometry technologies to solve analytical problems in environmental science. Additionally, students benefit from immersion in both academic and industrial experiences, which serves to enhance their professional development.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
While it is appreciated that both organic and inorganic sources of sulfur in the environment can contribute to global warming, acid rain, and environmental pollution among other phenomena, the full range of contributors to the sulfur levels that have been observed in the environment is not fully known or understood. Sulfur sources from the oceans are well catalogued, and those from volcanoes as well as various anthropogenic activities have been quantified. However, it has been noted that these sources by themselves do not balance the sulfur budget in the atmosphere. Previous work identified a range of terrestrial plant-derived potential contributors to the sulfur in the atmosphere. These compounds, such as thiosulfinates, are produced by agriculturally important cash crops such as garlic and onions that occupy large acreage worldwide. The potential for these compounds to behave as greenhouse gases raises the possibility that the farming of these crops creates organosulfur ?hotspots? that could negatively impact the environment. Therefore, this work sought to determine whether these compounds are themselves greenhouse gases, and also to determine their possible fates in the atmosphere when they are exposed to atmospherically relevant radicals, such as hydroxyl, chlorine, ozone and NOx radical species.

In the main, it was found that while thiosulfinates exhibit the characteristics of a greenhouse gas in principle (i.e., they have the property of absorbing infrared radiation emitted from Earth?s surface and reradiating it back to Earth?s surface), their lifetimes (only a few hours in the environment) are too short for them to have this impact.1-9 This is because they are rapidly removed through their reactions with environmental free radicals to form new products. Interestingly, the bulk of these new products are well-known greenhouse gases and environmental pollutants. They include hydrocarbons such as propylene; sulfenyl chloride; hydrochloric acid; formaldehyde; hydroperoxyl radical; sulfurous acid and sulfur dioxide. A major conclusion is that the thiosulfinates produced by some crops from the Allium genus serve as masked forms of sulfur dioxide and other greenhouse gases. The results provide important information on some of the possible heretofore unknown contributors to environmental and atmospheric sulfur. To date, the work has been disseminated in 14 journal articles1-14 and 10 presentations at conferences and other venues.

This project involved a collaboration with JEOL USA Inc., a global leader in electron optical and analytical equipment and instrumentation for high-end scientific and industrial research and development. In this regard, the integration of teaching and research between the project trainees (post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students) on the one hand, and the JEOL scientists on the other, unimpeded by departmental or administrative boundaries, cultivated a cultural shift in research-based instruction. The project provided employment for two postdoctoral trainees, 2 undergraduate students, 4 graduate students, and two visiting scientists. Broader impacts of the results of this work include the finding that mimics of the compounds that serve as precursors of the plant-derived VOSCs could be developed into anti-cancer agents.10-13 A terrestrial plant biofeedback inhibition mechanism that prevents collateral damage to plant tissue in response to injury was also discovered.14

REFERENCES
